fields.description:
Hi All,

A Problem found in EBS volume creation checks.

We have a monitoring script in house that runs and creates EBS volume, create snapshot from that volume and then deletes the volume and the snapshot. This script is run to keep a monitor on the health of our storage in the cloud.

When monitoring script check whether the cloud  can create EBS volume and Snapshot from it using NetApp Clustered Ontap, it usually destroys EBS volume, but leaves Snap-volume and EBS LUN to the storage system in the end.

For example, we see this:

{code}
Vserver Path State Mapped Type Size
--------- ------------------------------- ------- -------- -------- --------
acme10 /vol/snap_00893AD3/lun1 online unmapped linux 1GB
acme10 /vol/snap_024B3F42/lun1 online unmapped linux 1GB
acme10 /vol/snap_14223DF9/lun1 offline unmapped linux 1GB
acme10 /vol/snap_16E7400C/lun1 online unmapped linux 1GB
acme10 /vol/snap_17C44116/lun1 offline unmapped linux 1GB
{code}

It definitely checks everything correctly, but when it is time to clean things out, It sometimes get this snap-lun offine, sometimes it even cannot do that. And sometimes it destroys that volume and LUN.

These LUNs are removed from Euca databases, so Euca thinks that they are destroyed, but they are left to the disk and has to be removed manually.

It might be that some procedures might take some time. And our testing script has a shorter "wait" time and previous operation is still under progress when next operation is attempted and hence causes volume and LUN removal to fail.
fields.summary: NetApp Storage leaves eucalyptus snapshots (netapp volumes) in filer
fields.environment:
*non-HA*

* 1 x CLC, Walrus
* 2 x CC, SC (multi-cluster)
* 12 x NCs
* Managed-NOVLAN networking mode

comments.body: I have not seen any snapshots that are left behind if eucalyptus is running. If you create a lot of snapshots, ask them to be deleted and stop Eucalyptus all those snapshots will be left on the SAN. After system restart all snapshots were removed.

[~vasya], the issue was caused by failing database lookups on the SC. AFAIK no code change was involved in resolving this issue. If the SC cannot lookup the information about a volume/snapshot, then it errors out the deletion process.
[~swathi], I've run volume/snapshot create/delete cycles per [~hspencer] recommendation and have not seen left over snapshots. Let me know if you suggest any other bug verification approach.

Hi [~swathi]

What can we do to detect the situation when SC is "stuck" and unable to communicate to CLC. As far as we can tell the SC state has been ENABLED all the time.

If there is a reliable way to determine this problem please do let us know. We can communicate this back to the user.
[~hspencer], what do we need to get here? Logs from the filer?

[~lwade],

If you could, that would be great, and logs from the CLC and SC machines. 

Thanks man.
This is still being observed in 3.4.  Will focus on capturing information.

Update: Starting 3.3, we added INFO level messages in the SC to log high level requests. When the SC receives a delete snapshot request, it would be logged as "Processing DeleteStorageSnapshot request for snapshot snap_XYZ" in the cloud-output logs. I just skimmed through the logs and assuming that snapshot deletion was attempted while these logs were being captured, I expected to see log messages like the one above but did not find even a single one. When the user submits a delete snapshot request to the CLC, it should issue a delete snapshot request to the SC (cluster) that the snapshot was first created in and follow it by issuing the same request to SCs in the remaining clusters. I'll dig into this further and update the ticket.

[~swathi], please check SUP-365 for the logs and note the dropbox link.  If you look at the console_output.txt, that is from the filer and will show a large number of vols.  The ones which are almost guaranteed to be orphaned are the 1.26GB eutester volumes.  We've also attached the eutester script to see if we can replicate this.

Choose a snap:   sna-B7A94055.  This exists on the filer but not in Eucalyptus.

In the logs we see:

{code}
Fri Nov 1 22:14:15 2013 ERROR [BlockStorageController:pool-48-thread-1] [com.eucalyptus.blockstorage.BlockStorageController.isSnapshotMarkedFailed(BlockStorageController.java):1086] Error determining status of snapshot snap-B7A94055
Fri Nov 1 22:15:07 2013 ERROR [BlockStorageController:pool-48-thread-1] [com.eucalyptus.blockstorage.BlockStorageController$Snapshotter.run(BlockStorageController.java):1415] Failed to fire snapshot creation event for snap-B7A94055
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException:
Expected: not (null or an empty string)
     but: was null
        at com.eucalyptus.util.Parameters.checkParam(Parameters.java:47)
        at com.eucalyptus.util.Parameters.checkParam(Parameters.java:33)
        at com.eucalyptus.reporting.event.SnapShotEvent.<init>(SnapShotEvent.java:119)
        at com.eucalyptus.reporting.event.SnapShotEvent.with(SnapShotEvent.java:110)
        at com.eucalyptus.blockstorage.BlockStorageController$Snapshotter.run(BlockStorageController.java:1406)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:722)
{code}

Fix Approved.

Fix for better handling cleanup including retries was addressed in EUCA-8551 which also addresses this issue. Marking this verified as that has been verified.
